hotspots.label: Bright Yellow Stripes
hotspots.fact: These bold yellow and black stripes are a warning sign to predators that this caterpillar is toxic and tastes bad. Bright colors in nature are nature's way of saying 'Don't eat me!'

hotspots.label: Tentacle-like Antennae
hotspots.fact: These two dark tentacles on the caterpillar's head are called tentacles or filaments. They help the caterpillar sense its environment and find food by detecting chemicals in the air.

hotspots.label: Segmented Body
hotspots.fact: This caterpillar's body is divided into many ring-like segments connected together. This flexible segmentation allows the caterpillar to move in a smooth, wave-like motion as it crawls along branches.

hotspots.label: Host Plant Connection
hotspots.fact: This caterpillar is likely a Monarch butterfly caterpillar that eats milkweed plants. When it eats the milkweed, it absorbs toxins that make the adult butterfly poisonous to birds too!
